Title: Linking forum posts - howthingswork-05-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: Definition of the Newton
Input.posts:
Dear Prof Bloomfield, at the end of the lectures on 'skating' you arrived at Newton's second law and I thought this was the ideal time to define the unit of force to make the constant of proportionality equal to one. The advantage of this would have been seen in 'falling balls part 2' where you were obliged to call the Newton an 'esoteric unit'. Also, you would have avoided the 'wacky unit' of N/Kg for acceleration. In the end the Newton had to be defined anyway to make sense of the acceleration units. Defining the Newton early seems more logical to me. I am enjoying the course and am particularly impressed with the demonstrations (position one glance, velocity two glances, acceleration three glances was brilliant and more profound than it first appeared). However, Ido not see the point in persevering with the pound-force? It never was a useful unit in mechanics and in physics terms has no future. Cheers, Ken.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
I agree that introducing the Newton early would have made sense. Now that I have people helping to translate the videos, it's late in the game to edit them (except possibly by inserting graphics -- that might work). I persist in using the pound-force because of my long experience with students in the United States. They have grown up with the pound-force and trying to push them into using the Newton simply causes them added difficulty. They don't have a feel for a Newton and won't pick it up easily. I tried switching completely to SI units about 10 years ago in my live class. The result was lots of confusion and push-back. Short of a national initiative to shift from the old English or American units to the SI units, it's not going to happen here. What I mean to do eventually is insert graphic overlays whenever I use an English/American unit to display its SI equivalent (and perhaps vice versa). Lou

Input.threadtitle: Episode 3 Lecture 2.  Explanation of 'negotiation'
Input.posts:
I know this is a few weeks off, but... The explanation of the negotiation between the wagon and the sidewalk is a bit too anthropomorphic for my tastes and I am having a hard time understanding what that means? \xA0What is each object actually doing in that negotiation and in what sense can they detect whether each other is accelerating? \xA0Is there some other way of explaining this concept? Thanks so much. \xA0The lectures are great and for the most part quite understandable. \xA0I just got hung up a bit here.
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
I do tend to anthropomorphize the objects I discuss, perhaps because I have spent so much time in the world of objects that I see them as 'friends.' Nonetheless, I understand when others don't appreciate that habit of mine. The process (rather than negotiation) that occurs when you set a wagon on a sidewalk involves the same physics as the process that occurs when a person lands on a trampoline (or drops from a bungee cord, and so on). The person bounces up and down for a while until finally settling down at equilibrium (i.e., in a situation in which the person experiences zero net force and does not accelerate). Whenever the person is above that equilibrium, the person is under-supported by the trampoline, experiences a downward net force, and accelerates downward. That person will soon be heading downward and will coast through equilibrium. By 'coast through equilibrium' I mean that they will reach the equilibrium position (or height) and will suddenly be experiencing zero net force, but because they are moving downward, they will continue moving downward and overshoot the equilibrium. Similarly, whenever the person is below equilibrium, the person is over-supported by the trampoline, experiences an upward net force, and accelerates upward. That person will soon be heading upward and will coast through equilibrium. The person will bounce up and down about equilibrium until frictional effects waste their excess energy and all them to settle at equilibrium. By 'waste their excess energy', I mean that the seemingly endless bouncing will damp out as forces within the trampoline (and also the air) act to decelerate the bouncing person. Returning to the wagon on the sidewalk, the bouncing process occurs in a barely perceptible way, but it does occur. It must. And when the process is over, the wagon will be slightly denting the sidewalk -- just enough to cause the sidewalk to perfectly support the wagon. Hope this helps! Lou

Input.threadtitle: Episode 3 Lecture 2.  Explanation of 'negotiation'
Input.posts:
I know this is a few weeks off, but... The explanation of the negotiation between the wagon and the sidewalk is a bit too anthropomorphic for my tastes and I am having a hard time understanding what that means? \xA0What is each object actually doing in that negotiation and in what sense can they detect whether each other is accelerating? \xA0Is there some other way of explaining this concept? Thanks so much. \xA0The lectures are great and for the most part quite understandable. \xA0I just got hung up a bit here.
Upvotes:
1
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
I do tend to anthropomorphize the objects I discuss, perhaps because I have spent so much time in the world of objects that I see them as 'friends.' Nonetheless, I understand when others don't appreciate that habit of mine. The process (rather than negotiation) that occurs when you set a wagon on a sidewalk involves the same physics as the process that occurs when a person lands on a trampoline (or drops from a bungee cord, and so on). The person bounces up and down for a while until finally settling down at equilibrium (i.e., in a situation in which the person experiences zero net force and does not accelerate). Whenever the person is above that equilibrium, the person is under-supported by the trampoline, experiences a downward net force, and accelerates downward. That person will soon be heading downward and will coast through equilibrium. By 'coast through equilibrium' I mean that they will reach the equilibrium position (or height) and will suddenly be experiencing zero net force, but because they are moving downward, they will continue moving downward and overshoot the equilibrium. Similarly, whenever the person is below equilibrium, the person is over-supported by the trampoline, experiences an upward net force, and accelerates upward. That person will soon be heading upward and will coast through equilibrium. The person will bounce up and down about equilibrium until frictional effects waste their excess energy and all them to settle at equilibrium. By 'waste their excess energy', I mean that the seemingly endless bouncing will damp out as forces within the trampoline (and also the air) act to decelerate the bouncing person. Returning to the wagon on the sidewalk, the bouncing process occurs in a barely perceptible way, but it does occur. It must. And when the process is over, the wagon will be slightly denting the sidewalk -- just enough to cause the sidewalk to perfectly support the wagon. Hope this helps! Lou

As those of you in this thread have observed, without gravity the ball would only accelerates as you push it and would coast at constant velocity forever once it has left your hand. Gravity complicates the story by exerting its own force on the ball. About the duration of the force and the idea of instantaneous pushes: we will see in Episode 6 - Bumper Cars that forces transfer a conserved quantity known as momentum. Again neglecting gravity, your push on the ball transfers momentum to it. Once you stop pushing, the ball carries that fixed momentum with it and can't change its velocity as a result. It has to keep moving steadily in order to have the constant momentum. The momentum you transfer to the ball is the product of your force times the duration of your push (if the force varies with time, we'd need to us calculus to deal with the time-varying force). Thus you can get the ball moving with a certain momentum (and consequently a certain velocity) with a large force exerted for a short time, or a small force exerted for a long time. In principle, you can also get it moving that way with an infinite force exerted from an infinitesimal duration, as long as the produce of that infinite force times the infinitesimal duration is equal to the usual value. This trade-off between force and duration involved in momentum transfers is a hugely useful idea. It explains, for example, why you'd rather land in an airbag during a car crash than in the steering wheel -- you transfer the same momentum to the surface you hit, but with the airbag that transfer involves a smaller force for a longer duration than would be present if you hit the hard steering wheel. Hope this is useful. Lou

Input.threadtitle: Why does a body move at a constant velocity when there is no force applied?
Input.posts:
Ok, I know the short answer would be inertia. But does someone have a more intuitive explanation for the question? To me it seems like magic when I envision a body continuing to move at constant velocity without any application of force. For example, I envision a sort of ghost like figure which moves about in the air at a constant velocity with hands outstretched :). Maybe the answer to this question lies in the fundamental explanation of inertia?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
You are experiencing the same astonishment that Galileo and Newton must have felt when they understood inertia. It's simply not obvious or intuitive to us that objects move for free -- that they coast at constant velocity in the absence of any external forces. That's in part because we never see objects that are truly free of external forces; friction, air resistance, and gravity always mess things up. But in deep space, things really do coast essentially forever at constant velocity. We can get close be skating on ice or extremely good wheels. When you roll a hard ball on a hard level surface, it pretty nearly coasts at constant velocity. Lou

Hi Dermot, Inertia is only related to mass so for the question:\xA0Do heavier objects contain more inertia than light objects? Yes. Friction has no role in determining whether an object has more inertia. Friction just opposes the relative motion between two surfaces in contact. As for the question -\xA0 does gravity play a part in holding heavier objects stationery and thus conveying more inertia? No. All matter that has mass, has inertia. Linking inertia and motionless is incorrect and dangerous. I have not view the video yet, so I do not know if the lecturer introduce Newton's first law. Thanks Chin Chai. A heavy object is one with a large weight . An object with great inertia is one with a large mass . The two concepts involved -- weight and mass -- are different. Inertia is a characteristic of the object itself; weight is a force exerted on the object due to gravity. Nonetheless, those two quantities are related (something we'll see in Episode 2 -- Falling Balls). Here's how: It turns out that objects with great inertia (i.e., objects with large masses) are also quite heavy (i.e., objects with large weights) when there is gravity present. The remarkable thing is that gravity gives an object a weight that is exactly proportional to that object's mass (assuming everything is at the same location, because gravity can vary according to location). The profundity of that observation is hard to describe. Let me just say that it is the starting point from which Einstein developed his theory of general relativity. Lou
